data.text: Europe to be hit hardest in global slowdown -OECD
data.snippet: The global economy should avoid a recession next year but the worst energy crisis since the 1970s will trigger a sharp slowdown, with Europe hit hardest, the OECD said, adding that fighting inflation should be policymakers' top priority.

image.text: A file photo shows the skyline of Frankfurt, Germany, July 5, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: POLL-ECB set to raise deposit rate 50 bps as euro zone enters recession -economists
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The European Central Bank will press on with policy tightening, adding 50 basis points to its deposit rate next month as it worries rapid price growth is becoming entrenched, despite the bloc almost certainly entering recession, a Reuters poll found.

relatedHeadlines.text: ECB's Nagel opens door to smaller hikes but sees long way to go
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Bundesbank President Joachim Nagel opened the door on Tuesday to smaller interest rate increases by the European Central Bank but said there was still a long way to go in raising borrowing costs.

relatedHeadlines.text: UK government borrows less than expected in October, but worse to come
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Britain's government borrowed less than expected in October, data showed on Tuesday, although the budget deficit is likely to balloon in the months ahead thanks to energy bill support measures and a slowing economy.

relatedHeadlines.text: Almost one in five Germans dipping into savings to get by - poll
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Nearly one in five people in Germany have had to draw on their savings to cover everyday costs as rising inflation cuts into their purchasing power, a survey by the Kantar polling institute published on Tuesday found.

relatedHeadlines.text: BOJ's price gauge hits record high in sign of broadening inflation
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Japan's weighted median inflation rate, which is closely watched as an indicator on whether price rises are broadening, hit a record 1.1% in October in a sign of heightening inflationary pressure from rising raw material and labour costs.

relatedHeadlines.text: German 2022 industry output to rise slightly, 2023 looks gloomy - BDI
relatedHeadlines.snippet: German industrial production is on track to rise slightly this year thanks to order backlogs but the outlook for 2023 is gloomy as high energy prices and geopolitical uncertainties hurt businesses, the BDI industry association said on Tuesday.

data.text: EXCLUSIVE-Bankman-Fried's FTX, parents bought Bahamas property worth $121 mln
data.snippet: Sam Bankman-Fried's FTX, his parents and senior executives of the failed cryptocurrency exchange bought at least 19 properties worth nearly $121 million in the Bahamas over the past two years, official property records show.

image.text: View of the entrance to the condominium complex ONE Cable Beach, a beachfront residence in New Providence, Bahamas, November 18, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: U.S. prosecutors opened probe of FTX months before its collapse - Bloomberg News
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Crypto exchange FTX was on the radar of federal prosecutors in Manhattan months before its collapse, Bloomberg News reported on Monday citing people familiar with the investigation.

relatedHeadlines.text: Crypto lender Genesis says no immediate plans to file for bankruptcy
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Cryptocurrency lender Genesis said on Monday it has no immediate plans to file for bankruptcy, days after the collapse of crypto exchange FTX forced it to suspend customer redemptions.

relatedHeadlines.text: U.S. Senate to hold FTX hearing on Dec. 1, CFTC chairman to testify
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee on Thursday said it will hold a hearing on Dec. 1 to examine the sudden collapse of FTX, one of the world's biggest crypto exchanges.

relatedHeadlines.text: FTX had total cash balance of $1.24 bln as of Nov. 20
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Cryptocurrency exchange FTX, which has filed for U.S. bankruptcy court protection, had a total cash balance of $1.24 billion as of Nov. 20, according to a court filing on Monday.

data.text: EXCLUSIVE-China set to fine Ant Group over $1 bln, signalling revamp nears end-sources
data.snippet: Chinese authorities are poised to impose a fine of more than $1 billion on Jack Ma's Ant Group, said six sources with direct knowledge of the matter, setting the stage for ending the fintech company's two-year long regulatory overhaul.

image.text: A file photo shows a booth of Ant Group at the Singapore FinTech Festival, Singapore, November 4, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: UK begins investigation into Apple, Google's mobile browser dominance
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Britain's competition watchdog has launched an in-depth investigation into the market dominance of Apple and Google's mobile browsers, months after the regulator began considering a probe.

relatedHeadlines.text: Sony to expand Chinese game incubator in Microsoft head-to-head
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Sony Group Corp said on Tuesday it plans to expand a programme to identify and incubate Chinese-made games, in a race with Microsoft Corp to tap China's gaming market.

relatedHeadlines.text: China plans stiff fines in tech-related changes to competition law
relatedHeadlines.snippet: China's market regulator proposed amendments on Tuesday to a law on unfair competition, making provisions for fines ranging as high as a 5% share of a firm's annual revenue to punish such practices by internet companies.

relatedHeadlines.text: JD.com to slash top exec salaries amid China's 'common prosperity' push
relatedHeadlines.snippet: China's JD.com said on Tuesday it would cut the salaries of more than 2,000 senior managers by 10% to 20% next year to help pay for improved benefits for other staff amid the government's "common prosperity" drive to reduce income inequality.

data.text: Ukrainians brace for bleak winter as Russian strikes cripple power capacity
data.snippet: President Volodymyr Zelenskiy appealed to Ukrainians to conserve energy amid relentless Russian strikes that have already halved the country's power capacity, as the United Nations' health body warned of a humanitarian disaster in Ukraine this winter.

image.text: A file photo shows a woman shopping in a supermarket as Kharkiv suffers an electricity outage, amid Russia's attack on Ukraine, in Kharkiv, Ukraine, October 17, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: No immediate safety concerns at Zaporizhzhia after shelling, IAEA says
relatedHeadlines.snippet: There are no immediate nuclear safety or security concerns at the Russian-held Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine despite shelling at the weekend that caused widespread damage, the U.N. atomic watchdog said after its experts toured the site.

relatedHeadlines.text: Putin touts Russia's 'Arctic power' with launch of nuclear icebreakers
relatedHeadlines.snippet: President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday touted Russia's Arctic power at a flag-raising ceremony and dock launch for two nuclear-powered icebreakers that will ensure year-round navigation in the Western Arctic.

relatedHeadlines.text: Russia's 'General Armageddon' under pressure to deliver on battlefield after retreat
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Russia's leading war hawks rallied behind the humiliating decision for Moscow's forces to retreat from the Ukrainian city of Kherson this month, but the commander who argued in favour of the move is now under growing pressure to prove it was worth it.

relatedHeadlines.text: Ukraine's security service raids Kyiv monastery, suspects Russian sabotage
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Ukraine's SBU security service and police raided a 1,000-year-old Orthodox Christian monastery in Kyiv early on Tuesday as part of operations to counter suspected "subversive activities by Russian special services".

relatedHeadlines.text: INSIGHT-On Europe's new frontlines, red tape, politics and potholes hamper defence
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Military planners say that while the war has led to more awareness, the funding shortfall reflects a greater concern: Europe's political mindset, which Bessems said lags behind the reality of all-out war on European soil, and which has not come to terms with the hybrid nature of modern warfare.

relatedHeadlines.text: EXPLAINER-'Close call' at Ukrainian nuclear plant

data.text: GLOBAL MARKETS-Shares brush off China COVID curbs, dollar retreats
data.snippet: Global shares rose on Tuesday, recovering some of the previous day's losses, as improved investor risk appetite drove flows into equities and commodities, although concern over more COVID infections in China kept gains in check.

image.text: A file photo shows a trader working at the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, September 25, 2020.

relatedHeadlines.text: Rebound in oil stocks lifts European shares
relatedHeadlines.snippet: European shares rose on Tuesday, supported by a recovery in oil stocks after a rout in the previous session as investors weighed mixed signals from central bank policymakers on the path of interest rate hikes.

relatedHeadlines.text: Dollar steadies as China tightens COVID curbs
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The dollar steadied on Tuesday after rallying the previous day as investors flocked to the safe haven currency on worries over China's COVID flare-ups, while bitcoin came under pressure after fears of fresh contagion from the collapse of crypto exchange FTX.

relatedHeadlines.text: Euro zone bond yields rise amid mixed signals from ECB
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Euro zone government bond yields rose on Tuesday after falling the day before as expectations for peak rates in the current tightening cycle barely moved recently from around 2.9%.

relatedHeadlines.text: GRAPHIC-China leads global equity IPO volumes this year
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Chinese companies are at the forefront of global stock offerings this year, with their issuances being facilitated by easy monetary settings at home and a lack of clarity on access to offshore capital markets.

relatedHeadlines.text: Oil rises as Saudi comments outweigh recession concerns
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Oil rose on Tuesday after top exporter Saudi Arabia said OPEC+ was sticking with output cuts and could take further steps to balance the market, outweighing global recession worries and concern about China's rising COVID-19 case numbers.

relatedHeadlines.text: Gold advances on dollar pullback; spotlight on Fed
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Gold prices snapped a four-session slump to rise on Tuesday, propped up by a retreat in the dollar while investors awaited cues on the U.S. Federal Reserve's monetary policy path.

data.text: Beijing shuts parks, museums as China's COVID cases rise
data.snippet: Beijing shut parks, malls and museums on Tuesday while more Chinese cities resumed mass testing for COVID-19 as authorities struggle with a spike in cases that has deepened concern about the economy and dimmed hopes for a quick reopening.

image.text: A file photo shows workers in protective suits preparing to enter a building under lockdown to distribute to residents antigen testing kits for the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), at a residential compound in Beijing's Chaoyang district, China November 21, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: ANALYSIS-China's great reopening may come too late for many businesses
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The culinary tourism business of Brian Bergey and his wife Ruixi Hu has persevered in China through three years of harsh COVID-19 restrictions.

relatedHeadlines.text: Beijing city reports 634 new local COVID cases for 15 hours to 3 p.m. - official
relatedHeadlines.snippet:
China's capital Beijing
reported 634 new local COVID cases for the 15 hours to 3 p.m.
(0700 GMT) on Tuesday, the deputy director of city's municipal
Center for Disease Control and Prevention, Liu Xiaofeng said at
a briefing.
 (Reporting by Beijing newsroom; Writing by Liz Lee
Editing by Raissa Kasolowsky)
 ((liz.lee@thomsonreuters.com; Twitter: @livinglizly;))

nB9N31D02Q

relatedHeadlines.text: Chinese exchanges say COVID testing firms to face strict IPO checks
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Chinese stock exchanges said they will strictly vet listing applications from COVID-19 testing companies, in response to media reports voicing concerns over fundraising plans by beneficiaries of the pandemic.

relatedHeadlines.text: Japan's Shionogi shares jump after report of COVID drug gaining efficacy approval
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Shares in Japanese drugmaker Shionogi & Co Ltd rose nearly 3% by mid-morning on Tuesday after the Yomiuri newspaper said the country's regulatory agency had compiled a report confirming the possible efficacy of the company's COVID-19 drug.

data.text: Cryptoverse: Let's talk about DEX, baby
data.snippet: As the crypto castle crumbles, some true believers say the answer is to double down on DEX. Decentralized exchanges, that is.

image.text: Representations of cryptocurrencies plunge into water in this illustration taken, May 23, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: BREAKINGVIEWS-Hong Kong’s crypto push sets up race to bottom
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Few cities in the world have expressed a desire to throw open cryptocurrency trading to retail investors since the devastating collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried’s exchange. That puts Hong Kong in a league of its own.

relatedHeadlines.text: BREAKINGVIEWS-Coinbase’s problems more than contagion
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Coinbase Global’s founder Brian Armstrong wants to reassure investors that digital currencies are safe. That makes sense: Bitcoin and other coins are his company’s lifeblood. But the industry collapse is only one problem. Coinbase hasn’t figured out how to have a viable business in a downturn, and it already has debt to service.

data.text: ANALYSIS-Kohl's snub of big sale-leaseback sets up new clash with hedge funds
data.snippet: Kohl's Corp's reluctance to sell much of its real estate and then lease it back has set up the U.S. department store operator for a new confrontation with hedge funds.

image.text: A file photo shows a woman entering the Kohl's department store in Arvada, Colorado August 12, 2010.

relatedHeadlines.text: EXCLUSIVE-Buyout firm EnCap eyes first oil and gas production fund in five years -sources
relatedHeadlines.snippet: EnCap Investments is raising its first private equity fund in five years dedicated to oil and gas production, people familiar with the matter said, making it an exception among U.S. buyout firms that have fled the oil patch amid a scarcity of lucrative acreage and pressure from environmentalists.

relatedHeadlines.text: SocGen and Alliance Bernstein to launch global equities venture
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Societe Generale, France's third-biggest listed bank, and U.S. investment management company Alliance Bernstein plan to form a joint venture focusing on global cash equities and equity research, they said on Tuesday.

relatedHeadlines.text: Consumer credit rating firms need reform, says UK watchdog
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Britain's 'highly concentrated' consumer credit ratings market used for obtaining loans is not working well, and a new industry body to help improve the quality of scores is needed, the Financial Conduct Authority said on Tuesday.

relatedHeadlines.text: Carlyle sees big in Japan auto industry as EV shift shakes supply chains
relatedHeadlines.snippet: U.S. private equity firm Carlyle Group Inc aims to enlarge its footprint in the Japanese automotive sector as the global shift to electric vehicles (EVs) shakes the industry's supply chain, its executives said.

data.text: Don't like Musk? Work for us! Tech firms woo ex-Twitter staff
data.snippet: Put off by Elon Musk's muscular management style? Move to us! That's the pitch being used by talent-starved technology firms trying to lure thousands of former Twitter Inc employees laid off by the social media company under its new owner.

image.text: An image of Elon Musk is seen on a smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: Musk says Twitter to hold off relaunching blue check verification
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Twitter's new owner Elon Musk said on Monday the social media company is holding off the relaunch of its blue check subscription service, a delay from his initial tentative timeline to bring back the service on the platform.

relatedHeadlines.text: EU Justice Commissioner to meet Meta, Twitter executives in Dublin
relatedHeadlines.snippet: European Union justice chief Didier Reynders will meet executives from Twitter and Meta at their European headquarters in Dublin this week, the Irish Times quoted the commissioner as saying on Tuesday.

relatedHeadlines.text: 'Toxic Twitter' activists ramp up pressure on brands after Trump account reinstated
relatedHeadlines.snippet: A coalition of civil rights activists on Monday were urging Twitter's advertisers to issue statements about pulling their ads off the social media platform after its owner Elon Musk lifted the ban on tweets by former U.S. President Donald Trump.

data.text: ANALYSIS-China has limited power, and perhaps little desire, to curb North Korea
data.snippet: U.S. President Joe Biden last week asked his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, if he could try to talk North Korea out of a new nuclear weapon test but he acknowledged that he did not know if China had the capacity to do so.

image.text: A file photo of U.S. President Joe Biden shaking hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the G20 leaders' summit in Bali, Indonesia, November 14, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: U.S. calls for U.N. Security Council president's statement on North Korea missiles
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The United States called on Monday for a United Nations Security Council presidential statement to hold North Korea accountable for its missile tests after Pyongyang's launch last week of an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of reaching the U.S. mainland.

relatedHeadlines.text: U.S. Secretary of State says Saudi-U.S. ties under review despite Khashoggi immunity ruling
relatedHeadlines.snippet: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Tuesday his country's relationship with Saudi Arabia was still under review despite the administration's ruling that the Saudi crown prince has immunity from a lawsuit over the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

relatedHeadlines.text: North Korea accuses U.N. of double standards over missile test- KCNA
relatedHeadlines.snippet:
The sister of North Korean
leader Kim Jong Un said on Tuesday that the U.N. Security
Council showed a "double standard" over weapons development by
holding a gathering on its missile test, calling it a "grave
political provocation," state media KCNA said. 
 (Reporting by Hyonhee Shin
Editing by Raissa Kasolowsky)
 ((hyonhee.shin@thomsonreuters.com;))

nS6N2XD013

relatedHeadlines.text: U.S. stands with Philippines against coercion in South China Sea - Harris
relatedHeadlines.snippet: W ashington will stand by the Philippines in the face of intimidation and coercion in the South China Sea, U.S. Vice President Kamala Harris said on Tuesday while visiting the Palawan island in the disputed waters.

relatedHeadlines.text: ANALYSIS-In male-dominated North Korea, leadership prospects of Kim Jong Un's daughter are uncertain
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Although the unexpected appearance of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un’s daughter raised speculation that she could be a successor in the making, analysts say it would be an unprecedented uphill struggle in the male-dominated dynasty.

data.text: EU gas cap seen in place for one year, countries at odds over price level
data.snippet: The European Commission proposed introducing a gas price cap for one year from Jan.1, 2023, according to draft legislation seen by Reuters that has so far left the actual ceiling level blank.

image.text: A file photo shows European Union flags fluttering outside the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, September 28, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: Germany to retroactively cap gas, power prices in March -draft
relatedHeadlines.snippet: The German government plans to cap gas and electricity prices in March 2023 retroactively covering prices from January, according to a draft plan seen by Reuters on Tuesday.

relatedHeadlines.text: Iran starts enriching uranium to 60% purity at Fordow site - official
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Iran has begun enriching uranium to 60% purity at its underground Fordow nuclear site, the country's nuclear chief said on Tuesday, a move that may irk Western powers pushing Tehran to roll back its nuclear work by reviving a 2015 pact.

relatedHeadlines.text: COLUMN-Australia's LNG exporters have a no-win domestic dilemma: Russell
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Australia's liquefied natural gas exporters have a problem at home, where industrial and domestic consumers are making strident demands for them to accept a price cap, higher taxes, guaranteed volumes or some combination of all of these.

data.text: FOCUS-Generic drugmakers Teva and Sandoz make major push to biosimilars
data.snippet: Generic drug makers Teva Pharmaceutical Industries and Sandoz say they are planning a significant ramp-up in production of biosimilars – copies of high-priced drugs used to treat illnesses such as rheumatoid arthritis and cancer – aiming to increase their share of an expanding market.

image.text: A file photo shows the logo of Teva Pharmaceutical Industries in Tel Aviv, Israel February 19, 2019.

relatedHeadlines.text: GSK to stop selling blood cancer drug Blenrep in United States
relatedHeadlines.snippet: GSK will stop selling its blood cancer drug Blenrep in the United States, it said on Tuesday, representing the latest in a series of setbacks for the British drugmaker's oncology business.

relatedHeadlines.text: Drug maker Novo Nordisk invests $744 mln to expand Danish plant
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Danish drug maker Novo Nordisk said on Tuesday it plans to invest 5.4 billion Danish crowns ($744 million) to expand its facilities in Bagsvaerd, Denmark.

data.text: 'Boomerang CEOs' don't always work out; Disney hopes this one bucks trend
data.snippet: Can Walt Disney Co bank on another hit sequel? That appears to be the hope behind the company's surprise decision to bring back former chief executive BobIger to replace Bob Chapek.

image.text: A file photo of Disney's Chief Executive Officer Bob Iger speaking during the Bloomberg Global Business Forum in New York City, New York, U.S., September 25, 2019.

relatedHeadlines.text: Disney brings back Bob Iger as CEO in surprise move to boost growth
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Bob Iger is returning to Walt Disney Co as chief executive less than a year after he retired, a surprise comeback that coincides with the entertainment company's attempt to boost investor confidence and profits at its streaming media unit.

relatedHeadlines.text: Disney's media sales boss to exit in Iger shake-up
relatedHeadlines.snippet: A day after returning to the company, Walt Disney Co Chief Executive Bob Iger moved to undo a corporate structure put in place by his hand-picked successor.

relatedHeadlines.text: Disney says returning CEO Iger to get $1 million base salary
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Walt Disney Co said on Monday returning Chief Executive Robert Iger will get an annual base salary of $1 million and a long-term incentive award with a target value of $25 million.

relatedHeadlines.text: Disney's chairman, Daniel, to exit in planned restructuring
relatedHeadlines.snippet: One day after returning to the company, Walt Disney Co Chief Executive Bob Iger moved to undo a corporate structure put in place by his hand-picked successor.

data.text: Many school children among 252 dead in Indonesian earthquake
data.snippet: Many children were killed in an earthquake in Indonesia when their schools collapsed, officials said on Tuesday, as rescuers raced to reach people trapped in rubble in a devastated town on Java island.

image.text: Indonesia rescue members evacuate people from the site of a landslide caused by the earthquake in Cugenang, Cianjur, West Java province, Indonesia, November 22, 2022.

relatedHeadlines.text: 'Nothing was left': After Indonesia quake, families desperately search
relatedHeadlines.snippet: For hours Aris stared at an excavator working its way through mounds of earth on the Indonesian island of Java in the hope it might uncover some trace of his loved ones, missing after a 5.6-magnitude earthquake destroyed their home.

relatedHeadlines.text: Indonesia's national disaster agency: 151 people missing after quake
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Indonesia's national disaster mitigation agency said on Tuesday around 150 people remain missing after an earthquake hit the western part of Java island, killing 268.

relatedHeadlines.text: Buildings damaged but no tsunami warning for Solomon Islands after 7.0 earthquake
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Authorities in the Solomon Islands said no tsunami warning would be issued after two powerful earthquakes struck on Tuesday, damaging Australia's embassy, the airport and shopping malls and triggering power cuts in the capital, Honiara.

data.text: China's COVID resurgence delays oil demand recovery to after Q2 2023 -analysts
data.snippet: Analysts are cutting forecasts for China's year-end oil demand after COVID-19 cases surged to near record levels, forcing authorities to reinstate mobility curbs and delaying recovery at the world's top crude importer.

image.text: Pumpjacks are seen during sunset at the Daqing oil field in Heilongjiang province, China August 22, 2019.

relatedHeadlines.text: COLUMN-Oil prices retreat as investor sentiment darkens: Kemp
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Oil prices were hit by an abrupt reversal of sentiment last week, with investors selling at the fastest rate for four months, as the economic outlook worsened and fears eased that the G7 price cap on Russian crude would disrupt its exports.

relatedHeadlines.text: Saudi denies oil output hike discussion, says OPEC+ may cut if needed
relatedHeadlines.snippet: Saudi Arabia on Monday said that OPEC+ was sticking with oil output cuts and could take further measures to balance the market amid falling prices, denying a report it was considering boosting output, according to state news agency SPA.

relatedHeadlines.text: Big Oil joins farmers, biofuel groups to tout more ethanol in U.S. fuel
relatedHeadlines.snippet: A group of oil, renewable fuel and farm trade organizations have joined together for the first time to voice support for U.S. legislation that would expand nationwide of E15, a higher ethanol-gasoline blend, according to a letter from the group.
